user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of completed_callback:
```c
static void
completed_callback (void *cls,
                    struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    void **req_cls,
                    enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct timeval *tv = *req_cls;
  struct timeval tve;
  uint64_t delta;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == tv)
    return;
  gettimeofday (&tve, NULL);

  delta = ((uint64_t) (tve.tv_sec - tv->tv_sec)) * 1000000LL
          + (uint64_t) tve.tv_usec - (uint64_t) tv->tv_usec;
  if (delta < SMALL)
    small_deltas[delta]++;
  else
    fprintf (stdout, "D: %" PRIu64 " 1\n", delta);
  free (tv);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function completed_callback:
static unsigned int small_deltas[SMALL]
...
#define SMALL (1024*128)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
gettimeofday (&tve, NULL);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown code: completed_callback calls the POSIX gettimeofday function, which does not call completed_callback, so there is no direct or indirect recursion. A possible violating scenario would be if gettimeofday were replaced by a macro or wrapper that invoked completed_callback (directly or via another chain of calls), which would create indirect recursion and thus violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
